metadata.title: A model cathode for mechanistic study of organosulfide electrochemistry in Li-organosulfide batteries

Graphical abstract Any species that can attack S–S bonds and produce more electrochemically active M–S bonds could potentially serve as a mediator. Organosulfides offer new opportunities for high performance lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries because of materials abundance, versatile structures and unique properties. Yet, their redox kinetics as well as cycling performance need to be further improved. Employing redox mediators is a highly effective strategy to address above challenges. However, the underlying mechanism in this chemistry is so far insufficiently explored. Here, phenyl disulfide (PhS–SPh) and phenyl diselenide (PhSe–SePh) are used as a model system for mechanistic understanding of organosulfide electrochemistry, particularly the rate acceleration. Profiling the reaction thermodynamics and charge-discharge process reveals redox of both S–S and C–S bonds, as well as that the coupling between radical exchange and electrochemical redox is the key to enhance the sulfur kinetics. This study not only establishes a basic understanding of orgaonsulfide electrochemistry in Li-S batteries, but also points out a general strategy for enhancing the kinetics of sulfur electrodes in electrochemical devices. Keywords Organosulfide Radical exchange Reaction kinetics Rate acceleration 1 Introduction The increasing demands of grid-scale electricity storage, electric vehicles and portable electronics call for new battery systems with higher energy density beyond currently developed lithium-ion intercalation based techniques [1-4]. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) battery is considered to be a promising candidate due to its extremely high energy density of 2600 Wh kg−1, low cost and abundance of sulfur [5-8]. Organosulfides containing sulfur chains as active lithiation sites present unique electrochemistry [9-11]. Some organosulfides with high capacity, such as dimethyl trisulfide [12], dipyridyl polysulfides [13], diphenyl trisulfide [14], and stretchable polymers [15] have shown excellent battery performance in Li-S batteries. Such organosulfides could effectively overcome the problem of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) shuttling by generating less high-order LiPSs upon cycling [16,17]. However, the development of high performance organosulfides-based batteries was hindered by poor redox kinetics, which is tightly associated with poor conductivity of organosulfides as well as their reduced products, resulting in unsatisfactory cycling and rate performance [18-20]. It has been proven or shown that introducing selenium (Se) into sulfur cathodes can complement the poor conductivity and low electrochemical activity of sulfur [16,21]. Particularly, our group demonstrated a eutectic accelerator strategy to introduce small amounts of Se in small organosulfide molecular of sulfurized polyacrylonitrile cathodes to alleviate the shuttling effect and accelerate the reaction kinetics, yielding excellent cyclability and rate capability for Li-S batteries [22-30]. However, the underlying acceleration mechanism of organosulfide has been insufficiently explored [20,31-33]. Previously studies reported that there exists a nucleophilic substitution of alkyl halides or nitroaromatic halides by electrogenerated polysulphide ions [34-36]. The reaction of RS− and Se will form RSSe− ions, which can be oxidized into RS2R faster than RS− on a gold electrode [37]. Moreover, Anoutithe et al. conducted a comparative study on the impact of catholytes containing electrochemically active organic disulphide (R2S2), thiol (RSH) or dithiol (SHRSH) compounds on the discharge capacity and capacity fade rate of sulphur cathodes in Li-S batteries. They proposed a potential chemical balance between the redox systems (S8/S x 2−) and (RS x R/RS x −) in the solution. The long term cycling up to 500 cycles validated the positive effect of the organic catholytes as chemical barrier against sulphur loss during cycling [38,39]. Recently, redox mediators with reversible redox couples have been exploited to accelerate redox kinetics by regulating the chemical reactions of sulfur species [40-46]. For instance, Huang et al. introduced organopolysulfide (di-t-butyl disulfide, DtbDS) as a mediator to enhance the redox kinetics of sulfur, and a Li-S pouch cell under practical conditions is realized [47]. Herein, we use phenyl disulfide compounds as a model system to investigate the fundamental kinetics and mechanism of organosulfide electrochemistry. A small amount of PhSe–SePh as mediator was added into the PhS–SPh cathode to remarkably improve the battery performance, indicating its catalytic effect. Through both experimental and theoretical investigations, we conclude that a Se radical-mediated catalytic cycle that couples radical exchange and electrochemical redox is responsible for accelerating the sulfur kinetics. This work provides a deep understanding for mechanism of organosulfide, which could offer guidance for constructing high performance Li-S batteries. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials 1,3-dioxolane (DOL, 99.5%, Sigma-Aldrich), 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME, 99.8%, Sigma-Aldrich), lithium nitrate (LiNO3, 99.99%, Sigma-Aldrich) and phenyl disulfide (PhS–SPh, 99.8%, Sigma-Aldrich), phenyl diselenide (PhSe–SePh, 99.9%, Sigma-Aldrich), carbon disulfide (CS2, 99%, Sinopharm Chemical), lithium bis(trifluromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich) and lithium perchlorate (LiClO4, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich) were purchased and used as received. The commercial binder-free carbon nanotube paper called buckypaper (NanoTechLabs, Inc) was used as the current collector in this study. The carbon paper (CP) was cut into discs with diameter of 10 mm and dried at 100 °C for 24 h in a vacuum oven before use. 2.2 Sample preparation Synthesis of phenyl selenosulfide (PhS–SePh): Equimolar PhS–SPh and PhSe–SePh were mixed in DME solvent. The solution was stirred for 2 h and DME was removed by evaporation. The product was obtained for further analysis. 2.3 Theoretical calculation To simulate the radical exchange process between S and Se in PhS–SPh system, first-principles DFT calculations using Gaussian 16 software were performed. All calculations were based on the B3LYP hybrid functional with Grimme’s D3 dispersion energy correction, the molecular geometries were optimized using the 6-311G* basis set, and the single-point energies were calculated using 6–311+G(d,p) basis set for the optimized structures. Polarization continuous model (PCM) was used to simulate the solution environment in the battery. The calculation formula of the reaction enthalpy for radical exchange reaction is: E S–Se + E S*−(E S–S + E Se*), where E S–Se and E S* are the energy for the final state of S–Se and S*, and E S-S and E Se* are the energy for the initial state of S–S and Se*, respectively. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements Electrolyte and catholyte preparation: The electrolyte is composed of 1.0 M LiTFSI in a mixture of DME and DOL 1:1 (vol%), containing 2 wt% LiNO3. 1.0 M catholytes were prepared by adding appropriate amounts of active materials (PhS–SPh, PhSe–SePh, or PhS–SePh) to the electrolyte. The electrolyte and catholytes were prepared and stored in glove box. Additional, for the TEM and XPS test to verify the existence of Li2S, the lithium salt is LiClO4. 2032 coin cells assembled in an argon-filled glove box were used to test the electrochemical measurements with lithium foil as the anode. First, catholytes (25 μL) were added into the CP current collector. Then a Celgard 2400 separator was placed on the top CP followed by adding another 15 μL blank electrolytes. Finally, lithium metal anode was placed on the separator, and cell was crimped. Galvanostatic charge/discharge profiles were obtained at different C rates by battery test system (LAND-CT2001A, Wuhan, China). The cyclic voltammetry (CV) and linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) profiles were performed by electrochemical workstation (Solartron 1470E) at a scan rate of 0.2 mV s−1 between 1.8 and 2.8 V. Lithium ion diffusion coefficients for PhS–SPh and PhS–SePh based cells were calculated based on Randles-Sevick equation through a series of CVs with different scan rates. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were also tested on Solartron 1470E by AC impedance method. To demonstrate the catalytic effect of Se radical in organosulfide cathodes, very little amount of PhSe–SePh was added in the PhS–SPh based cathode, and the battery performance was tested. In detail, a certain amount of PhSe–SePh was dissolved into 1 mL of 1.0 M PhS–SPh catholyte, in which the molar ratio of S in PhS–SPh to Se in PhSe–SePh is from 20:1 to 10:1. Then the cell was assembled by the above method. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 presents a proposed reaction mechanism of Se mediated organosulfide. The discharge process undergoes two stages which feature breaking of S–S bonds and C–S bonds, respectively. Reductive breaking of S–S bonds in the first stage is the major and desired process in Li-S batteries. We believe that this process is more complicated than the straightforward two-step linear reaction pathway. Instead, it could proceed via a cyclic reaction involving a radical exchange. Importantly, this allows the whole reaction to be accelerated via a Se radical-mediated catalytic cycle, which is the theme of this work and will be elaborated on later. In the second discharge stage with lower voltage, C–S bonds in organosulfide are broken, leading to the formation of R–S–SLi and Li2S. During the recharge process, R–SLi and R–S–SLi are delithiated, forming a series of organosulfide compounds including R–S–S–R and R–S–S–S–R. This process should be partially irreversible. It may contribute to formation of SEI and can be controlled for better cycling stability and rate capability. 3.1 Mechanism for breaking S–S bonds The reductive breaking of S–S bonds could occur via a cyclic reaction pathway instead of a more straightforward linear pathway. The key distinction between the two is the role of S radicals. When an R–S–S–R molecule takes up e− and Li+, it generates the final products of R–SLi and an R–S· radical. There are two possible fates of R–S·, being further reduced to R–SLi to complete the reaction, or reacting with another R–S–S–R via fast radical exchange. At the first sight, it makes no net contribution to the overall reaction rate since the reactants and products of this self-exchange reaction are the same. A closer inspection suggests that the cyclic mechanism offers an opportunity to accelerate the slow rate of S–S breaking by introducing redox mediators such as PhS–SePh. PhS–SePh can be introduced by simply adding PhSe–SePh into PhS–SPh. As proven by our experimental results as well as other reported work, PhS–SePh will be produced automatically via the exchange reaction between PhS–SPh and PhSe–SePh at room temperature (Figs. S1–S7) [15]. This is further supported by our density functional theory (DFT) calculations using several methods including (B3LYP-D3/6-31G*//B3LYP-D3/6–311+G(d,p), B3LYP-D3/6-311G*//B3LYP-D3/6–311+G(d,p), M06-2X/6-31G* and M062X/6-311G* (Table S1). All results indicate that the bond dissociation energy (BDE) for PhS–SePh is greater than PhS–SPh, demonstrating that the S–Se bond is stronger than that of S–S. More importantly, BDE of the S–Se is greater than the average of that of S–S and Se–Se, which demonstrates that the exchange reaction is thermodynamically favorable. Reduction of R–S–Se–R could form either an R–S· or an R–Se·. The S radical generating pathway is uninteresting as the S radical is indistinguishable from that formed via reducing R–S–S–R. In contrast, the Se radical could induce new chemistry. It can attack an R–S–S–R molecule and the radical exchange will result in an R–S· and another R–S–Se–R molecule. This “new” R–S–Se–R molecule will be lithiated to form R–SLi and R–Se· in another incidence of reduction reaction. Importantly, this process “reproduces” an R–Se· and the net results is consumption of R–S–S–R and production of R–SLi, making up a Se-radical mediated catalytic cycle. For this catalytic cycle to effectively accelerate the reduction rate of R–S–S–R, at least a few criteria must be met: (1) R–S–Se–R must be more reactive than R–S–S–R; (2) R–S–Se–R, when reduced, should preferably produce R–Se·; and (3) the radical exchange reaction between S· and Se· must favor S· as the product. In the following, we present the evidence for each of them. The higher reactivity of R–S–Se–R can be referred from electrochemical measurements, which will be elaborated on later. As discussed earlier, PhS–SePh can be reduced via two possible pathways, into PhSe· and PhS–, or into PhS· and PhSe–, as illustrated in Fig. 2 (a). It has been proved that the pathway 1 for formation of Se radical is more likely to occur [48,49]. This is unsurprising considering the fact that S is a more electronegative element than Se. Once a Se radical is generated, it could attack S–S to obtain a S radical. This exchange reaction is simulated using DFT calculations (Fig. 2(b) and Table S1). As shown in Fig. 2(b), the reaction generally goes downhill with no significant barrier, driven by a significantly negative reaction enthalpy of − 9.145 kCal/mol. This is consistent with our earlier result that S–Se bond is stronger than S–S. Therefore, the Se radical should be more active in radical exchange than the corresponding S radical. In comparison, the reaction enthalpy for symmetric PhS· exchange must be 0, as illustrated. The differential electrochemical behaviors of R–S–S–R and R–S–Se–R are key to the acceleration of the overall-rate of whole reaction. We performed a series of electrochemical measurements to compare the electrochemical behaviors of S–S and S–Se bonds. Fig. 3 (a) shows the CV of Se mediated PhS–SPh cathodes, which are initially cycled for 10 cycles to reach a stable electrochemical state before experiments. In general, they exhibit similar features, with one pair of oxidation and reduction peaks. However, the peak position is different, demonstrating different electrochemical activity. Compared with PhS–SPh and PhS–SePh cathodes, PhSe–SePh is more easily reduced or oxidized. Besides, the voltage gap between the reductive/oxidative peaks for PhS–SePh is greatly decreased when compared with that of PhS–SPh cathode, suggesting that PhS–SePh is more favorable in the redox reaction despite of stronger S–Se bonding. Therefore, PhS–SePh is electrochemically more reactive than PhS–SPh, albeit more stable thermodynamically. Moreover, we tested the electrochemical behavior of Se mediated PhS–SPh cathodes, in which a small amount of PhSe–SePh was added in the PhS–SPh catholytes. Fig. 3(b) shows the LSV results of the Se mediated PhS–SPh cathodes. It can be seen that the reduced peaks are positively shifted as quantity of PhSe–SePh increases. A series of experiments (Fig. S8) suggest that a molar ratio of Se in PhSe–SePh to S in PhS–SPh at about 1:15 is an optimal choice. The reduction peak of such a cathode is almost the same with PhS–SePh. Compared with PhS–SPh cathode, the PhS–SePh enjoys a much lower overpotential of 0.23 V (Fig. 3(c)), indicating better redox activity, which is in consistence with the CV results. The Li+ diffusion capability and EIS were also measured to investigate the electrochemical behavior of Se mediated PhS–SPh cathodes. The calculated Li+ diffusion coefficient from different scan rates of CVs of PhS–SePh cathode are about 3 times higher than that of PhS–SPh in both discharge and charge processes (Fig. 3d, Figs. S9–S13). Similarly, the resistance impedance of PhS–SePh cathode is much lower than that of PhS–SPh (Fig. 3e). When compared with pristine PhS–SPh cathode, the Se mediated PhS–SPh cathode shows much higher Li+ diffusion coefficient and lower resistance impedance. With only 1 out 15 of S being replaced with Se, the Li+ diffusion coefficient is almost as high as that of PhS–SePh. Similarly, the resistance impedance of such a cathode decreases remarkably to a value that is slightly higher than that of PhS–SePh. To summarize, the Se mediated PhS–SPh cathode, compared with PhS–SPh, shows significantly lower overpotential and resistance impedance, and higher Li+ diffusion capability. Importantly, only 1 out 15 of S being replaced with Se is necessary to improve the performance of the cathode to the level of PhS–SePh, an effectively 1:1 mixing ratio of S and Se. Finally, we test the electrochemical performance of Se mediated PhS–SPh cathodes in full cells. Fig. 3(f), Figs. S14–S18 and Table S2 show the cycling performance of PhS–SPh batteries with and without PhSe–SePh at the current density of 0.2 C. Since the introduction of too much PhSe–SePh in PhS–SPh will lower the overall theoretical capacity of the cathode, selecting an appropriate amount of PhSe–SePh is critical to achieve the best mediation effect. Optimization experiments (Fig. S17) show that the PhS–SPh: PheS–SePh = 15:1 (molar ratio of S to Se) gives the best ratio to achieve the best cycling performance. After 100 cycles, the Se mediated PhS–SPh cathode exhibits much higher capacity of 127.5 mAh g−1, corresponding to a higher capacity retention of 67.2% than that of PhS–SPh cathodes (27.9%). The capacity of 100 cycles is even better than that of PhS–SePh cathode (120.1 mAh g−1), though the PhS–SePh cathode do exhibit a little higher capacity retention capacity of 73.5% than Se mediated PhS–SPh cathodes. Overall, this acceleration effect of Se radicals can indeed greatly enhance the sluggish kinetics of PhS–SPh cathode to a level comparable to that of pure PhS–SePh. Fig. S19 shows the mass spectrometry (MS) results of Se mediated PhS–SPh cathode at charged and discharged states. The discharged products of organosulfides include similar components (PhSLi, PhS–SLi, PhSeLi, PhSe–SeLi, etc.) with that of PhS–SePh cathode but with different abundance (Fig. S20), and similar phenomenon was observed for the charge process (Fig. S21). Moreover, the Se mediated PhS–SPh shows much improved rate performances, compared with pristine PhS–SPh battery (Figs. S22–S24). In detail, the Se mediated PhS–SPh battery delivers better rate capability at high current density (146.9 mAh g−1 at 2.0 C, respectively), while for PhS–SPh battery, it declines to 123.7 mAh g−1 at 2.0 C. Thus, the battery performance of PhS–SPh is dramatically improved with the addition of PhSe–SePh. Furthermore, the surface morphology of the corresponding Li anodes after cycled was also investigated for the Se mediated PhS–SPh cells (Fig. S25). It displays a uniform, continuous and highly packed morphology, suggesting that the introduction of organoselenide does not aggravate the corrosion of metal lithium. All these observations are consistent with our notion that S–Se bonds have better redox kinetics than S–S bonds, and a Se radical-mediated catalytic cycle that couples radical exchange and electrochemical redox accelerates the kinetics of organosulfide. 3.2 Mechanism for breaking C–S bonds In the second discharged stage at lower voltage, C–S bonds in organosulfide are broken, which can be confirmed through characterizing the structure of charge/discharge products of PhS–SPh by high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis. Fig. 4 (a) and Fig. S26 show the MS results of PhS–SPh cathode after first cycle at the discharged state. There are two peaks at 3.903 and 4.119 min, which are ascribed to PhSH and PhS–SH, indicating the formation of PhSLi and PhS–SLi, respectively. The PhSLi is the dominant species due to its high intensity of peak in MS analysis, and existence of PhS–SLi should result from breaking of C–S bonds in organosulfide which will form Li2S. The XPS spectra of S 2p for PhS–SPh at first discharged state further indicate the compositions of inorganic sulfides (Li2S) and organosulfide-containing components (Fig. 4b and Fig. S27). Specially, the S 2p 3/2 peak binding energy of 162.4 eV is assigned to Li2S. And two S 2p3/2 peaks at 162.8 and 164.0 eV represent PhSLi and PhS–SLi, respectively. When delithiated, the charged products of PhS–SPh and PhS–S–SPh will be formed, as demonstrated in MS results (Fig. S28). Similar phenomenon is founded in the discharged and charged products of PhSe–SePh cathode (Figs. S29 and S30). Moreover, Fig. 4(c–f) present the HR-TEM images of PhS–SPh cathode after first cycle at discharged state. The lattice fringes of Li2S is clearly identified, and lattice with interplanar distances of 0.332 nm matches well with (111) planes of Li2S (Fig. 4e). Furthermore, the corresponding selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (Fig. 4f) shows diffraction rings ascribed to reflections of Li2S phase. These results all verify the existence of Li2S, which can only be formed via breaking C–S bonds in PhS–SPh. The resulted Li2S could form soluble lithium polysulfides and S8 species in the following charge/discharge process, leading to irreversible loss of capacity. Through optimizing the chemical structure of organosulfide, the formation of carbon anions and Li2S could be suppressed. It is worth mentioning that breaking C–S bonds is rare and it happens alongside the breaking of S–S bonds, making it very difficult to detect using current characterization techniques, such as Raman spectroscopy. With the advance in in-situ characterization techniques, it may be possible to in-situ investigate the change of C–S bonds during the charge and discharge process. 3.3 General strategy to accelerate the kinetics of organosulfide Using Se-mediated phenyl disulfide as a model system, we demonstrate a strategy of coupling a fast radical exchange and electrochemical redox reaction to circumvent the sluggish kinetics of organosulfides. This Se radical-mediated catalytic cycle somehow resembles a relay race. While the redox of S–S could occur on its own, the kinetic is slow and could be accelerated by a “relay runner” or a mediator. Unlike typical catalysts in chemical reactions, such a mediator (and its related species) must be both an electrochemically active and a chemically active species. In our case, R–S–Se–R is more facilely reductive with a potential matching that of disulfide and its reduction generates the key mediating species of Se–R, which is chemically reactive towards disulfide bonds. Another distinction with typical catalysts is that Se–R will eventually be reduced, losing its “catalytic” activity. In the context of rechargeable battery, this should be regarded as a desirable property since it contributes toward the capacity. We believe this reaction scheme is broadly applicable. Although we studied on a disulfide, the strategy should work for polysulfide-based systems, which are more practical cathode materials. In fact, the Se has been shown to accelerate the rate of several types of Li-S batteries [23-26]. Moreover, any species that can attack an S–S bond and produce a more electrochemically active M–S bond could potentially serve as a mediator as shown in Fig. 5 . For example, Te, the heavier analogy of Se, is expected to work in a similar fashion. Indeed, we have previously reported enhancement of the cycling and rate performance of organosulfide-based cathodes with a small additional amount of Te [27-30]. This chemistry is not limited in chalcogen-based species. The general scheme may help explain the effects of other redox mediators, such as metal-based mediators (metals [50], metal oxides [51], nitrides [52] and sulfides [53]) and organic redox mediators (DtbDS [47], anthraquinone derivatives [43], benzo[ghi]pery leneimide [54], etc.). Via chemisorption, surface catalysis, or introducing extrinsic redox mediators, the conversion of lithium polysulfides is dramatically accelerated to enhance the overall sulfur redox kinetics. This work provides a new insight to uncover the mediation mechanism of redox mediator for high-performance sulfur cathodes. Along with anticipated improvements in lithium anode and electrolytes, it brings the Li-S battery a step closer to practical realization. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we have conducted a systematic investigation to elucidate the mechanism of organosulfide electrochemistry using phenyl disulfide compounds with and without additional Se compounds as a model system. The study of reaction thermodynamics and charge/discharge process suggests that the reaction pathway involves a Se radical-mediated catalytic cycle that couples radical exchange and electrochemical redox can dramatically enhance the reaction kinetic of organosulfide. This work provides deep understanding for mechanism and accelerating effect of organosulfide cathodes, and inspires further exploration in mediating redox kinetics of sulfur for high performance Metal-S batteries. Moreover, advanced testing technology such as electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) coupled with battery charge and discharge test system may be performed to in-situ study those radicals participated electrochemical reaction for deeply uncovering the inherent reaction mechanism in the future. coredata.dc:description: Organosulfides offer new opportunities for high performance lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries because of materials abundance, versatile structures and unique properties. Yet, their redox kinetics as well as cycling performance need to be further improved. Employing redox mediators is a highly effective strategy to address above challenges. However, the underlying mechanism in this chemistry is so far insufficiently explored. Here, phenyl disulfide (PhS–SPh) and phenyl diselenide (PhSe–SePh) are used as a model system for mechanistic understanding of organosulfide electrochemistry, particularly the rate acceleration. Profiling the reaction thermodynamics and charge-discharge process reveals redox of both S–S and C–S bonds, as well as that the coupling between radical exchange and electrochemical redox is the key to enhance the sulfur kinetics. This study not only establishes a basic understanding of orgaonsulfide electrochemistry in Li-S batteries, but also points out a general strategy for enhancing the kinetics of sulfur electrodes in electrochemical devices.

coredata.dc:title: A model cathode for mechanistic study of organosulfide electrochemistry in Li-organosulfide batteries
